title: CTRL0000051198 - Transcribed Interview of Zac Martin, (Mar. 9, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The deposition in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 12:36
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
So we'll go on the record at 12:36 p.m.
This is a transcribed interview of Zachary
Martin conducted by the House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
on the United States Capitol pursuant to House resolution 503.
At this time, I'd ask the witness to please state your full name and spell your last
I have a couple of questions.
We have a few more people
on here from last time and it looks maybe some court reporters, so I'm just wanting to get
an idea of who we've got.
make sure I understand who everybody is and everything like that, if that's all right.
There's a few more than with the Quicks, so I just want to
So everyone -- it's the same number of attorneys as last time, me
will be taking down the statements from Mr. Martin here today.
nothing is being shared outside of the committee, not working with DOJ or anything like
that, except for the two exceptions that
efficiency measure that we've been taking on the committee to make sure we're
accurately capturing what the witnesses are saying.
And rather than us taking notes, we just have a stenographer here that
And that's -- but you guys didn't do that in the Quicks one, right?
doing it for most of them, but I'm not sure.
I think you guys just took notes in that one.
one second to get settled and talk to him really quick.
So we'll take a quick recess then at 12:37.
So we can go back on the record at 12:42 p.m. Eastern Time.
So this will be a staff-led interview, and members may join, although I
don't see any on the call right now, but if they were to join, they are also able to ask
an investigative counsel, and in the room with me today is
So at this time, could counsel please state your name for the record.
And can you just confirm, just in case your paralegal
said anything on the record, that her name is Teresa Funk?
There's an official reporter transcribing the record of this interview.
until each question is completed before you begin your response, and we will try to wait
until your response is complete before we ask our next question.
cannot record nonverbal responses, such as shaking your head, so it is important that you
answer each question with an audible verbal response.
head or nodding, I'll just note for the record and we'll keep going.
And if I see you shaking your
So we ask that you provide complete answers based on your best recollection.
the question is not clear, just please ask for clarification.
If you do not know the answer,
So I'm going to go through a couple of important things about this transcribed
at any time you would like to stop speaking with us, that is your choice.
any point you need to discuss something with your attorney in private, please let us know
and we will take a break so you can have that opportunity.
First, it's important that you understand that this interview is voluntary.
Second, this interview is not under oath, but because this is a formal congressional
investigation, you are obligated under Federal law to tell the truth, the same as if you
were speaking with the FBI or the Department of Justice.
information could result in criminal penalties for false statements.
And for this interview, providing false
Do you understand that, Mr. Martin?
Third, you are not obligated to keep the fact of this interview and what we discuss
prosecutor or judge in your case, or you can tell no one at all.
You are free to tell whomever you wish that you met with us, including the
Fourth, the select committee is separate and independent from the Department
with the select committee in its investigation.
to your criminal case, and we are -- it is not agreeing to submit anything on your behalf to
the judge, nor can we make any representation whether if you tell the judge that you met
with us, that the judge will be more favorable to you during sentencing.
We have no involvement with the prosecutions, and DOJ is not a partner
The select committee also is not a party
Fifth, we have agreed with your attorney not to share the substance of what you
say with the Department of Justice prior to your sentencing.
was unaware of or, if we had reason to believe you lied during this interview, then we
If you told us about evidence of a crime that we thought law enforcement
would be obligated to tell DOJ or another appropriate law enforcement agency.
And if you tell the judge that you met with us, please understand that may prompt
questions from the judge about what you said and whether it is consistent with your prior
we may get asked to respond and divulge what you said.
And if the judge starts asking questions,
Logistically, you know, if you need any breaks or if you need to speak with
Ms. Sumners about something, just let us know, happy to take a pause and move on from
is also on the call, if both of us start
asking a question at the same time, or if a member joins and multiple people are asking
and you can't hear us for whatever reason, just say so.
And if you don't understand, please just ask me to clarify because that
So let's start with a little bit of your background.
What month and what date in 1976?
I live in -- I have a Rogersville, Missouri address.
And have you -- how long have you lived there?
Where did you grow up before -- or where did you live before that?
Before that I was kind of traveling around in an RV.
I kind of like lived in an
RV and just moved from place to place.
My oldest daughter is 16 years old today
actually, and that's when we -- when I -- when we were pregnant with my first kid we
moved to Rogersville, and actually, like, bought a house and, you know, settled down.
So before that I -- I traveled.
I lived in Colorado for a while.
I went from -- I mean, I lived out in California for a while.
Yeah, just kind of traveled around in an RV basically.
So, well, what is your educational background?
I don't really have any college -- I don't have any college education.
And happy birthday to your daughter.
a GED, and that's really the, I mean, the extent of it.
You know, I have some -- I've done
a lot of -- I've had a lot of different jobs, so, I mean, I consider that part of my education --
-- but, yeah, that's -- basically GED and that's about it.
So what is your current job?
My current job is I'm -- I have an event property.
events, festivals, gatherings, school dances, you know.
host whatever kind of stuff they do there.
I have a barn and we do -- we
I also have a disc golf course out there.
That's just basically a, you know -- it's a donation thing.
know, it's not really part of the business, but people come out and play and if they want
to donate something they can, so -It sounds like your daughter will have a lot of fun places to have our 16th
It's a private course, but, you
She's got -- well, they're going to Eureka Springs for
the -- for her, I guess, birthday weekend, so that's going to be cool.
Well, thank you for that background information.
talk about the lead-up to January 6th.
questions are just to orient you to like President -- former President Trump's first term, so
really 2016 when he gets elected until before the November 2020 election.
timeframe, what would you say your level of political engagement was?
So this is going to be -- these next set of
Well, the first full year of Trump's -- I actually voted for Obama.
mom -- my mom was still alive.
You know, she was -- my mom was hard-core
this was like before, you know, like basically 2016 when all that was going down.
whatever, just I was like everybody else.
And so I was like -- I was the opposite.
I --1 did not --1 was like everybody else.
And then, you know, I mean, I didn't like him for a long time and it took me a while
to actually like -- the whole Russian collusion thing and all that, I started watching some of
that and started paying attention to it, and it just kind of like -- it was just annoying and it
just seemed like something was off and, you know, so I just decided to give Trump a
chance and actually listen to him.
This was probably like a year or so into his -- I believe it might have been like his
first -- maybe the second State of the Union, but that's what I listened to.
listened to that, I was like -- I was like, I kind of think this guy actually cares about this
I started to change my opinion.
And then once I realized that -- what had actually been happening, that everybody

political -- you know, it just -- it motivated me to sort of, you know, stand for what I now
believed in, which was, you know, our country.
I was proud to be American, versus before, I was like the exact opposite.
like arguing with people, you know.
And I was actually proud of America and
I'd go out and like argue with people, and so -I appreciate the background on the political views,
but -- so the specific question was more about how engaged you were.
what I get -- what I'm gathering, it sounds like you got more politically engaged as
Like as soon as I went to -- I mean, as soon as I switched
sides, I guess, I was pretty heavily -- I was a lot heavier politically engaged for sure.
So how -- I heard you mention listening to
President Trump's State of the Union, so direct source.
No, you know, I really didn't pay a whole lot of attention to the news at the

so, I mean, I couldn't help, because everywhere I went and everywhere, it was just like
that's what they were talking about.
I mean, before -- before that, before I switched sides, I mean, I would have
So I wasn't really -- I didn't really watch a whole lot
What would you say your primary source of political information
to say it would have to be the news, it would have to be television and like NPR, you
I wasn't a big TV person, but I listened to the radio quite a bit.
I listened to NPR a lot back then, so, I mean, a lot, you know, of
And after you, for lack of a better phrase, switched sides or began to support

Yeah, I pretty much -- I pretty much got the -- I got the clue.
that the mainstream media was pretty much not trustworthy at that point in time, so, I
mean, that included the radio and everything.
So I started to look for other sources of

Yep, I was definitely on Facebook.
I mean, Parler didn't work out very well, I don't
think, so -- but, yeah, not very much.
Not -- not until just like the last -- just recently, you know, not that long ago.
So not during the time period we --
I mean, I really -- I mean, it was pretty much just Facebook honestly.
mean, I wasn't on it very much.
I mean, I think I -- I don't remember when I started to get on Twitter, but, I
So fair to say Twitter, you might have had an account but you didn't really

If I used it, it was just to, like,
I never really got on there.
from 4chan, you know, from like people that would make, you know, YouTube videos
back then before they got banned from YouTube, but yeah.
4chan, but I never physically personally got on 4chan.
So, I mean, I was aware of

I saw people like, you know -- you're probably talking about, you know -- I'm

were, you know, going through that and they were talking about that kind of stuff on
know, what -- you know, so, yeah.
And they were just sort of decoding what does this mean, you

that was -- that was pretty much my main thing, but --
And were you searching -- actively searching out news or did it come

Well, no, I mean, I wasn't really actively searching.
because of the links, you know, just type of stuff I was looking at, it kind of just came to
And I wasn't -- I mean, I didn't really have a whole lot of different news

But, I mean, there was a few different, you know, IPOT, I-P-O-T, 1776, a couple

were very do your own research, you know, Don't take my word for it, you know,

know, usually just local, local people from around here, you know.
And do you remember any of the other names of the channels or
My favorite ones back then, I mean, I love Amazing Polly.
P -- no, P-o-1-1-y, Amazing Polly, yeah.
Those were my -- I mean, I don't know.
I'll come up with some other ones.
I can't think of them right now, but --
I can give you the list of the ones I currently listen to, if you want.
We'll get there, but thank you.
So did you follow President Trump on
Yeah, I mean, I would say, I mean, if he --1 don't really remember him being
very active on Facebook, like actual -- actually President Trump.
along -- you know, I followed people, and I was -- I would join a group that was supporting
So let's move a little bit to after the election.
the November 2020 election, did you believe that the election had been stolen?
And what gave you -- what made you believe that?
Well, I don't know how to put all -- I mean, that's a big -- there's a lot to that,
Well, let's start with like who were you following that gave you information
to believe that the election had been stolen?
Well, okay, for one thing, I mean, it was plainly obvious to me that, you
know, Biden didn't campaign, and if he did campaign, like I don't think anybody showed
that -- that right there was like night and day for me.
And if Trump threw a rally, it was like hundreds of thousands of people.
He had run for President two previous times and not
made it, but then this time he magically got more votes in the history of America?
mean, nothing made sense to me.
obvious that, you know, the bellwether counties, I mean, that's never happened.
Nobody's ever won that many bellwether counties and lost the election before.
so many different things, I mean, I could just go on and on about that.
It was just all to me plainly
why I didn't think that the election was legit.
So you had -- fair to say you had strong views about it.
and correct me if I'm wrong, so were some of these ideas percolating before the 2020
I mean, I pretty much assumed that like Trump was going to win for sure,
I mean, I thought he was going to win.
There was no possible way that Biden was going to win the election, so, yeah, I
mean, those ideas were definitely percolating before that.
I think everybody thought he was going

Bide n's not campaigning or Trump's rallies have hundreds of thousands of people, were
you seeing on that online beforehand?
Yeah, that's all over -- yeah, that was all over, you know, he wasn't
I mean, he was hiding in his basement, yeah.
I mean, that was just -- I mean,
that was in my sleep so, you know, it's like that was just common knowledge.
So you mentioned earlier that -- and I think this might be -- you were
referencing Q that taught you to do your own research.
That Biden didn't campaign and that President Trump had hundreds of
Did you ever check the veracity
thousands of people at his rallies?
I mean, I don't -- I don't know if I understand that question, but, no, I

was just -- that was just right in my -- I mean, that was just obvious.
I mean, that was -- I mean, yeah.
I don't know about the claims, what claims you're talking about,
If you're talking about Q posts that claimed that he wasn't doing his research
I'm just saying you stated these, what you call to be
So I was asking you if you verified them in any way?
No, no, I didn't -- that's just my opinion.
I didn't -- I'm saying my opinion
and I believe that everybody else's opinion probably too, at least in my realm of people,
was that Biden was not campaigning and that he couldn't draw a crowd even if he wanted
Even if he was campaigning, it was like a bunch of empty circles in a basketball
So given your strong views about the election, following the election and

political activity that alleged -- about alleged voter fraud?
Were you participating in on line chats or groups?
Basically all I did was Facebook, you know, and I would just -- I would

with a bunch of my old friends that I used to have that -- before I switched sides, you
just trying to convince -- to show people what I thought was actually happening, what I
Like they're calling me racist and meth head and all kinds of stuff.
And that's basically -- and it was all on Facebook.
go anywhere else besides Facebook at the time.
And at the time, was Q still an active community?
I mean, they stopped -- I think they stopped like, you
but it seems like almost up until before -- right, you know, the election.
I don't remember exactly when the post stopped going,
And I know you said you didn't attend any political rallies, so just for

Do you remember hearing about those rallies on Facebook?
And also between -- so after the election and before

And now we're going to move sort of into January 6th.
like what made you want to go to Washington, D.C.?
Not specifically, but, you know, it was just -- you know, I just -- it -- Trump,
you know, the -- everybody was like we've got to go show that we support, you know,
and just show our faces and, you know, this is a thing.
up and show our support, you know, and just show that we think -- oh, sorry -- just show
that we think that, you know, that the election was stolen and, you know, hopefully
It was -- we were called to show

That's just kind of like a -- it's a loose term sort of.
just called as patriots to show up and show our support.
don't know specifically who called, you know, but like there's a movie that was made

I mean, I -- it's a loose term.
You mentioned President Trump, were -- did his

I don't -- I don't know that it did.
I'd say, I mean, it probably did.
you know, it's like, I mean, but I -- not heavily, no.
already -- either -- I'd either already made my decision that I wasn't going to go or not, or
You know, I was or wasn't going to go, but --
Why did you think you had to be in D.C. on
Just to show my support as a patriot for America and that I believe that the
election was, you know -- the election was stolen, and I believe that.
to show that I just want to be a person, a face that was there, standing with all the other
people that were there saying that, Hey, we're all in this together.
I'm sorry for not being clear.
I didn't have anything special about the date.
So what made you realize that January 6th would be the date that
people would gather in Washington, D.C.?
I mean, I was just -- this is another thing, it was just common knowledge.
Everybody -- everybody was talking about that this was -- are we going to D.C. on the 6th
or what, you know, this is our last -- last chance to do anything, if anything, just show our
I don't know why the 6th was the day.
So why did -- where did you get the idea it was the last chance to show
Because, I mean, the election was, you know -- the election had been stolen,
and we were just called to -- I mean, I don't know why it's the last chance or whatever,
but I just showed up there to show my support, that I believe that the election was
stolen, and that, you know, we -- we're, as people of the United States, we believe this.
So, I mean, that's -- I don't know, man.
That's okay if you don't know.
paying attention to on line at this point.
were in or actively engaging with?

they were just groups that I would like grab memes and information from and, you know,

know -- like I didn't go anywhere beyond Facebook basically.

I mean, I should be able to remember.
just like VouTube people that were, you know -- that were just doing stuff, you know,

Just show support for America and our freedom and our God-given rights.
mean, that's what we felt -- we felt like our rights were being taken away from us, so --
That's what he wanted us to do was to show up and show support for

I mean, that's all I knew anyways.

Trampled, I don't remember saying trampled anything.
Whatever the word you used, you said violated or you wanted to show
support for rights and the Constitution.
But why did you feel the need to show support?
Because we felt that our rights were being taken away, our freedoms were
I mean, our election -- we believe that the election was stolen, so,
That was actually -- that was my question, so I appreciate the
So let's talk about heading to D.C.
When did you leave for Washington, D.C.?
It might have been the 4th, I think.
straight there, so -- I mean, we didn't stop anywhere, so I think we got there the night of
Like I just can't remember time very well, but just for future questions.
I think we left like super early in the morning, if I remember right, but I could

Of course, the Quick brothers and my friend Kari Kelly.
Is that Stephen and Michael Quick?
Do you remember Kelly ever calling it a caravan that you were driving?
Did -- do you remember Kelly ever calling it a caravan whenever you were driving?
Do you remember where you stayed in Washington, D.C. or if

Yeah, we stayed just out of town, you know, maybe 30 minutes away.

Just so -- in your sense of what would

was going to be any violence at all actually.
to be some sort of, you know, anti-pro -- you know, protests against us, but, I mean,
I mean, we didn't know what was going to
It was going to be a big event.
We didn't know if there was going
I wasn't like -- I wasn't worried

you remember seeing any Q posts about violence on January 6th?
I actually don't think there's any Q posts

I do know that the word

And I wasn't like a huge -- I mean, I didn't,
like, follow the Q posts like every single day or anything.
I mean, I really didn't even
I never got on the board and
so -- that looked it up and were talking about it.
you know, follow the Q thing.
know a whole much -- you know, a bunch about it, but --

something, so -- I mean, I don't know.

are leaving our room and headed to the action?

mean, you saying that, yes, that does seem like she did post something like that, but I

how many people were going to be there, but I knew there was going to be a lot of

of figured Trump was going to -- you know, for sure was going to say something and

I guess, but you knew President Trump would speak?

1 mean, there was a whole lot of -- there was a whole lot going on there.

I just -- I was just showing up to
And did you hear President Trump speak?
Do you remember him saying something, and I'm going to quote

Sorry, I didn't mean to interrupt.
But, I mean, I don't think he just stopped, you know.

He did, but I'm asking you about the specific sentence and how you took it to

right thing and show our support.
That's what fighting means, you know.

That's what I'm showing support for.
Trump was the President at the time when the election was stolen, but that's not why we

We were there for the Constitution.
We were there for our rights.
were you going to ask something?

probably to do something, you know.
He could -- you know, I don't remember exactly

I really didn't understand how all that worked, but, I

You don't remember hearing anything about the certification of the 2020
